title: 110_hr634
content:
The "American Veterans Disabled for Life Commemorative Coin Act" recognizes the sacrifices of disabled veterans and aims to mint a commemorative silver dollar coin in their honor. Congress acknowledges the service and sacrifices of veterans from various wars and emphasizes the importance of honoring those who have served and those who have made the ultimate sacrifice for their country. The "American Veterans Disabled for Life Commemorative Coin Act" aims to honor disabled veterans by minting a commemorative silver dollar coin. The coin specifications include a weight of 26.73 grams, a diameter of 1.500 inches, and a composition of 90% silver and 10% copper. The coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The design of the coins will symbolize the service of disabled veterans. The "American Veterans Disabled for Life Commemorative Coin Act" aims to honor disabled veterans by minting a commemorative silver dollar coin with specific designations and inscriptions. The design for the coins will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with relevant organizations, and the coins will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities from a designated mint facility. The "American Veterans Disabled for Life Commemorative Coin Act" specifies that the coins should be minted at the United States Mint at West Point, New York. The Secretary can only issue coins during the calendar year starting on January 1, 2010. The coins will be sold at a price including face value, surcharge, and production costs. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted at a reasonable discount before issuance. SEC. 7. SURCHARGES.
All sales of coins issued under this Act shall include a $10 surcharge per coin. Surcharges received will be paid to the Disabled Veterans' LIFE Memorial Foundation to support the construction of the American Veterans' Disabled for Life Memorial in Washington, D.C. The Comptroller General of the United States will audit the Foundation's expenditures. No surcharge may be included if it would exceed the annual limit of commemorative coin programs. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue guidance for programs exceeding the annual commemorative coin program limit under section 5112(m)(1) of title 31, United States Code.
